[File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: serialize()] [Integer Overflow] In the serialize() implementation, can extremely large version, block_height, or epoch values (near i64::MAX) cause overflow when converted to strings via ToString::to_string(), potentially corrupting BigQuery data or causing panics? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: serialize()] [Data Integrity] Does the serialize() method properly handle the optional payload and state_checkpoint_hash fields, or can None values lead to inconsistent BigQuery schemas where some transactions have missing fields that break analytics queries? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: serialize()] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker craft Transaction objects with extremely large string fields (hash, payload, vm_status) that cause excessive memory allocation during serialization, leading to OOM conditions in BigQuery streaming services? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: serialize()] [Field Count Manipulation] In lines 12-18, the len variable is calculated based on optional fields - can race conditions or concurrent modifications during serialization cause len to be incorrect, leading to incomplete serialization and corrupted BigQuery records? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Type Confusion] In the deserialize() implementation's visit_map() method, when deserializing version, block_height, epoch, and other i64 fields using NumberDeserialize, can an attacker provide values outside the valid range causing integer overflow or underflow that corrupts transaction data? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Field Validation] Does the deserialization logic validate that version, block_height, and epoch values are non-negative, or can negative values be injected that break assumptions in downstream transaction processing logic? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Hash Collision] The hash, state_change_hash, event_root_hash, and accumulator_root_hash fields are deserialized as strings without validation - can an attacker inject malformed hash strings that don't match expected hex formats, causing downstream hash verification failures or state inconsistencies? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Gas Manipulation] When deserializing gas_used (u64) at lines 229-235, can an attacker provide u64::MAX or other extreme values that bypass gas accounting validation and allow transactions to exceed legitimate gas limits? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Success Flag Tampering] The success boolean field is deserialized without validation - can an attacker flip this flag to mark failed transactions as successful in BigQuery, corrupting analytics data and hiding transaction failures that should be investigated? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [VM Status Injection] The vm_status field is deserialized as an arbitrary string - can an attacker inject malicious or malformed VM status codes that don't match the actual execution result, causing mismatches between BigQuery data and on-chain state? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Missing Field Exploitation] Lines 289-306 use ok_or_else to validate required fields, but the error messages only indicate which field is missing - can an attacker exploit missing field errors to probe the deserialization system and identify which fields are required vs optional? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Type Coercion Attack] When using NumberDeserialize for integer fields, can an attacker provide floating-point numbers that get silently truncated or rounded, causing data loss or incorrect values in critical fields like gas_used or num_events? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Timestamp Manipulation] The inserted_at field (i64 timestamp) is deserialized without validation - can an attacker provide future timestamps, negative timestamps, or timestamps beyond reasonable ranges that corrupt time-series analytics in BigQuery? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Event Count Tampering] The num_events field is deserialized as i64 - can an attacker provide negative values or values that don't match the actual event count, causing discrepancies between transaction data and event logs? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Function: deserialize()] [Write Set Manipulation] The num_write_set_changes field is deserialized without validation - can an attacker provide incorrect counts that don't match actual state changes, hiding or misrepresenting the transaction's impact on blockchain state? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Field: block_height] [Block Height Manipulation] Can an attacker deserialize transactions with incorrect block_height values that don't match the actual block they were included in, corrupting block-based queries and making it impossible to reconstruct the correct blockchain state from BigQuery data? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Field: hash] [Hash Format Validation] The transaction hash field is deserialized as a plain string without hex validation - can an attacker inject non-hex characters, incorrect lengths, or SQL injection payloads that corrupt BigQuery tables or break hash-based lookups? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Field: type] [Type String Injection] The transaction type field accepts arbitrary strings - can an attacker inject custom type values that don't match the actual transaction types (e.g., 'user', 'genesis', 'block_metadata'), causing type-based filtering queries to return incorrect results? [File: aptos-core/protos/rust/src/pb/aptos.bigquery_schema.transaction.v1.serde.rs] [Field: payload] [Payload Size Limit] The optional payload field can contain arbitrary strings - is there a size limit enforced during deserialization, or can an attacker provide gigabyte-sized payload strings that exhaust memory and crash BigQuery streaming services?
